channel.title: Posts on koolaidxk1d
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on koolaidxk1d

item.title: Snippets
item.description: Make WSL2 accessible via LAN Powershell: netsh interface portproxy add v4tov4 ` listenport=X ` listenaddress=0.0.0.0 ` connectport=Y connectaddress=z.z.z.z Replace X with your desired LAN facing port, Y with your WSL2-side port, and z.z.z.z with the ip of your WSL2 installation (find using hostname -I) To Undo: netsh interface portproxy delete v4tov4 ` listenport=X ` listenaddress=0.0.0.0

item.title: OverTheWire: Natas
item.description: Back for more password hunting! This time we are doing a more web-oriented wargame. Similarly to leviathan, no hints are given on the webpage. This game provides no SSH access; everything is done in the browser. I’m lacking in web-dev knowledge to say the least, so this will be quite challenging. Level 0 The password is right in your face the moment you look at the html. Level 1 Same story as level 0, however the workaround is just using the hotkey to open the inspector.

item.title: Cool Links
item.description: Services Susflix - free netflix clone, better movies evoxt.com - cheap VPS, good customer support real-debrid.com - very cheap, unlocks all paid filehost websites (1fichier etc.). Also converts torrents to direct http downloads. A must-have for movie obtainers. https://pixeldrain.com/ - free file uploading, no signup no bs (also has paid plans) Web Tools Regex101 - helps you make regex expressions deepl/translator - better than google translate Photopea - photoshop clone, free, no signup

item.title: About Me
item.description: Y2K zoomer interested in offensive security. No professional experience … yet. The purpose of my blog is to learn in public. Hopefully by writing these posts I can not only help myself but possibly help others who stumble upon them. Thanks This blog is written with Obsidian, compiled with Hugo, and hosted with Github pages. The Hugo theme in use is Diary.

item.title: OverTheWire: Leviathan
item.description: OverTheWire’s Leviathan wargame is all about reverse engineering of x86 binaries. The description of the game states that it only requires knowledge of linux command line utilities, and little to no programming experience. Each level goes as such: You ssh into the server as the user whose password you obtained from the previous level. Through whatever means necessary, you get the password to the next level. There are no hints given for any of the levels, so it is completely up to us to figure out what we are looking for.
